text: this is Roger Cohen in Cairo for the New
York Times 18 days may not seem like
long for a revolution but during that
time that was quite a lot of boredom
quite a lot of sitting around waiting
for things to happen and I think in the
end that was a good thing because a lot
of conversations that had never happened
in Egypt before took place when the
canonical ahead of me little i persevere
and I had nicked a sack of alumni had
any when a Vanessa Marano cumin I will
have certain telephone immortality'
these were conversations between the
westernized Egypt young people often
Thorin educated living abroad who'd come
back and the Islamist Egypt these two
parts of Egypt hadn't really known each
other before so it was a kind of
breakthrough I remember one conversation
in particular between a young Egyptian
woman living in Geneva who'd rushed back
to Cairo when she saw the scenes in
Tahrir Square and a 40 year old muslim
brotherhood member big black beard these
two people previously would not have
spoken to each other and what emerged
from their conversation was that they
might differ about certain things say on
whether people should be allowed to
drink in public but their view of an
Egypt with strong democratic
institutions coincided the other very
important cultural breakthrough and this
is true of Egypt and I think also the
wider Arab world is this sense suddenly
that you're an actor in history rather
than merely an object of history that as
a human being you can do things which
change things
previously I think here in Egypt
Egyptians felt after 30 years under
Mubarak that they just had to suffer
whatever the regime did this I think
could have an important transformative
effect on the Arab world because what's
the effect of powerlessness when you
feel you can't do anything as an
individual one is that you see
conspiracies everywhere and the Arab
world has always been full of these
conspiracies that either America or
Israel or somebody was controlling their
lives and that in the end is very
negative now I think you'll have people
who believe they can do things another
difference is that if you feel your life
is worth nothing you're probably more
likely to find an appeal in fanatical
movements that say hey come to us
subsume your identity into these utopian
destructive often suicidal beliefs and
your life then we'll have some value so
I think on all those fronts these
changes in Egypt have been very
important both of course for this
country and to the wider Arab world
